content: Where does the word "daisy" originate from?

The word "daisy" has an interesting etymology. It comes from the Old English term "dæges eage," which literally translates to "day's eye." This name was given because the flower's petals open up in the daytime, resembling the sun, and close at night. Over time, "dæges eage" evolved into "daisy" in Middle English. So, the name reflects the flower's behavior of opening and closing with the daylight.
